title: If I send a Word document over email, can the recipient see when it was last modified? - Quora

response.answer_text: MS Word has some pretty sophisticated collaboration features. Among those is the option to track changes, so that you can find out who made the latest changes, and when they were made. Also, Word files contain metadata that says when a file was created or modified. This information might not be accurate when a file is downloaded from an email. Your computer might just show the “modified” date as the date and time of the download. (I’m using Linux right now, so I can’t check. The file manager I’m using shows when a file was modified and when it was accessed.

Basically yes if you send the document as a file attachment.. Then whatever state you'd left the word document In will be available for discovery. If you wish to send a clean document (always a good choice) then do a copy/paste into a new document save and send that…. Leave your master document alone… So basically have 2 copies in your repository the mast document with tracked changes… and the clean Base version which you implement into your systems for doing mail merges etc and send in confidence to clients….
